I can use conditionals and variables to relate the movement of my â€œheroâ€ and scenery sprites.

Good programming habits in your code:

  • Using Start and Stop blocks.
  • Making sure you initialize appropriately so that your program is repeatable.
  • Use conditionals and variables, not precisely timed waits.
  • Add comments to your code so it is easy to understand.

Example

You should layer these sprites relative to â€œHeroâ€ and each other. Â

Following with the layers, scenery sprites should move at different speeds so that one seems farther away. Â 
Scenery sprites should roll over/reappear when they hit the edge of the stage. Â

Using Start and Stop blocks.

entry.title: ğŸ‘Œ SNAP Final Project
entry.content:
ğŸ¤– Overview

Platform games are among the most widely recognized types of video games. Composing about one third of all console games at the peak of their popularity, platform games are characterized by their relative simplicity and by the common gameplay element of jumping across suspended platforms (hence the name) to avoid falling into a hazard. Platform games also typically include enemy characters, items that grant the hero special abilities (â€œpower-upsâ€), and a â€œcheckpointâ€ system that allows the player to restart from partway through a game or level when he or she dies.

Details

1âƒ£ Hero Your program should have a â€œHeroâ€ sprite. You will be designing this character (a simple stick figure will suffice, if your art skills are like mine). â€œHeroâ€ should respond to user input. Specifically:

  • â€œHeroâ€ should clearly â€œfaceâ€ the right when you push the right arrow key
  • â€œHeroâ€ should clearly â€œfaceâ€ the left when you push the left arrow key
  • â€œHeroâ€ should jump when you push space bar
  • â€œHeroâ€ should perform an animated walk when you hold left or right arrow key

2âƒ£ Scenery You should have scenery sprites that move based upon â€œHeroâ€ traveling on the level. It is up to you to decide the level scenery, but you should meet the following requirements:

  • There should be at least two scenery sprites (Example: A mountain and a tree) You should layer these sprites relative to â€œHeroâ€ and each other. For example, â€œHeroâ€ should always be â€œin frontâ€ of any background scenery sprites
  • Scenery sprites move relative to â€œHeroâ€ as she moves. For example, when you hold down the right arrow key, the background sprites should move from right to left in the stage.
  • Following with the layers, scenery sprites should move at different speeds so that one seems farther away. For example, a faraway mountain should move more slowly than a nearby tree.
  • Scenery sprites should roll over/reappear when they hit the edge of the stage. For example, when â€œHeroâ€ is walking to the right, the scenery Sprites should re-appear on the right side of the stage when they roll off the left.

3âƒ£ Enemy There should be an on-ground enemy for â€œHeroâ€ to contend with. Specific criteria here include:

  • There is at least one on-ground enemy
  • The enemy sprite moves towards â€œHeroâ€, independent of whether â€œHeroâ€ is moving (e.g. regardless of whether the user is pressing an arrow key).
  • The enemy sprite reappears/rolls-over when it hits the edge of the stage
  • The enemy sprite is animated when it is moving towards â€œHeroâ€
  • If â€œHeroâ€ does not jump, she runs into the enemy and the game ends with an appropriate message (HINT: you can use the â€œSTOP ALLâ€ block to end all scripts)
  • It should be possible for â€œHeroâ€ to jump over the enemy.

Programming

I am looking for you to incorporate good programming habits in your code:

  • Using Start and Stop blocks.
  • Making sure you initialize appropriately so that your program is repeatable.
  • Use conditionals and variables, not precisely timed waits.
  • Add comments to your code so it is easy to understand.

Extensions (for the 4âƒ£!)

Once you complete the above, you can extend your program. Some suggestions:

  • Include flying enemies for â€œHeroâ€ to dodge or duck
  • Keep score based on how many objects â€œHeroâ€ gets by [Hint: Use a variable and show it on the screen]
  • Have â€œHeroâ€ jump to â€˜grabâ€™ an object that offers â€œHeroâ€ extra points or more powerful abilities (such as jumping higher or not being killed when she runs into an enemy). The objects must appear at random times and move smoothly as â€œHeroâ€ runs

Rubric

The detailed list for what I will use to grade your projects is below. Please review your projects before submitting to be sure you meet all of them.

Requirement Value
â€œHeroâ€ turns to the right on right arrow key 5
â€œHeroâ€ turns to the left on left arrow key 5
â€œHeroâ€ performs an in-place animated walk if you hold down either arrow key 5
â€œHeroâ€ jumps based on some input 5
There are least two scenery sprites 5
Scenery sprites are layered with â€œHeroâ€ (e.g. appropriate layering blocks are in your program) 5
Scenery sprites move based on â€œHeroâ€ movement 5
Scenery sprites move at different speeds (e.g. far away versus near) 5
Scenery sprites roll over when the fall of the stage 5
There is at least one on-ground enemy 5
Enemy sprite always moves towards â€œHeroâ€ 5
Enemy sprite re-appears/rolls over correctly 5
Enemy sprite is animated when it moves 5
If â€œHeroâ€ does not jump, she runs into the enemy and the game ends nicely and properly 10
â€œHeroâ€ can jump over the enemy 5
Good programming #1: Program has clear start and stop 5
Good programming #2: Program is repeatable and initializes state correctly 5
Good programming #3: Use of comments in your code 5
Good programming #4: Use conditionals and variables, not precisely timed waits. 5
Extra Credit: Include flying enemies for â€œHeroâ€ to dodge or duck 5
Extra Credit: Keep score based on how many objects â€œHeroâ€ gets by 5
Extra Credit: Have â€œHeroâ€ jump to â€˜grabâ€™ an object that offers â€œHeroâ€ extra points or more powerful abilities. The objects must appear at random times and move smoothly as â€œHeroâ€ runs 10
Extra Credit: Create Your Own Extension 0-10
TOTAL POINTS 100

entry.title: Lab 4âƒ£.0âƒ£ Lists
entry.content:
Create a variable for each part of speech below, and set each variable to hold a list of words that fit that part of speech. Some examples are given, but feel free to use your own.

Part of Speech Definition Example Words
noun person, place, or thing giraffe, monkey, boy, girl, elephant, â€¦ peopleâ€™s namesâ€¦
verb action word jumps, runs, sleeps, sits, dances, â€¦
adjective describes a noun big, small, loud, silly, young, old, sleepy, â€¦
adverb describes a verb or an adjective quickly, excitedly, angrily, happily, sadly, â€¦
article introduces noun: the book, a giraffe a, the
preposition relates a noun to something else under, over, around, near, beside, â€¦

Write a custom reporter block called â€œnoun phraseâ€ that reports a noun phrase where each word is chosen randomly from the lists you created. A noun phrase consists of an article, an adjective, and a noun in that order.

Write custom reporter blocks like noun phrase for each of the phrase types listed below.

Block name Construction
prepositional phrase preposition, noun phrase
verb phrase adverb, verb, preposition phrase
sentence phrase noun phrase, verb phrase

Write code so that when you press the spacebar, a random sentence is generated and a sprite says a sentence.

Changing Our Vocabulary

  1. Write a script so that when the â€˜nâ€™ key is pressed, the user is prompted for a new noun and that noun is added to list of nouns. After that point, the new noun entered by the user should be able to appear in sentences.
  2. Write scripts to add words to the other lists. Use the keys listed below.
Key Part of speech
v verb
j adjective
d adverb
a article
p preposition

entry.title: ğŸ”¢ Lists!
entry.content:
Learning Targets

I can create, modify, and access lists in SNAP.

Do Now (on paper)

Write an algorithm to reverse the order of any sentence.
For example, your algorithm would make the Do Now turn into:

â€œSentence a of order the reverse to algorithm an write.â€

Pseudocode

sentence = word_1 + word_2 + word_3 + â€¦ + word_n

ecnetnes = word_n + â€¦ + word_3 + word _ 2 + word_1

We need variables But we donâ€™t know how many.

Variables vs. Lists

Variables store a single value in a single location. Lists store multiple values in a single location.

List Traversal

Looking at each element of a list in order and performing some operation.

ex. Say each personâ€™s name, count the number of May birthdays, find the average GPAâ€¦

When working with lists, we need to create an index variable to keep track of position.

SNAP (and Python!) have built in split and join functions to separate lists into individual pieces of data, and to combine individual pieces of data into a list.

Letâ€™s get some practice:

Create a new SNAP project called â€œLists.â€ In that project, you will create

ğŸ›£ Highway Writing

Build a block to reverse the order of a sentence by word.

ğŸ”„ Sdrawkcab

Build a block that reverses the order of a sentence by splitting it into a list.

entry.title: Lab 3âƒ£.0âƒ£ Guessing Game
entry.content:
In this lab, you will use conditional statements and variables to build a simple number guessing game.

Section 1 - Iâ€™m Thinking of a Numberâ€¦

You will write a SNAP program to choose a random number between 1 and 10 and then ask the user to guess a number.

If the userâ€™s guess matches the random number, the user wins. If not, the user loses. In either case, the user should be shown a message indicating whether she won or lost and the secret random number should be revealed.

  • Write the simple version of the guessing game program described above.
  • Modify the program to keep asking the user for guesses until the correct number is given. Be sure to give a message after each guess, but only reveal the secret number when the user has guessed correctly and the game is over.
  • Add code to ask the player their name at the start of the game. Then, personalize the message for an incorrect guess by adding the playerâ€™s name. For example, if Scout is playing the game, then the message should say â€œSorry, Scout, that guess is not correctâ€ instead of just â€œSorryâ€ when Scout guesses incorrectly.

Section 2 - Game Upgrades

  • Modify your guessing game so that the player can decide the range of possible numbers from which the secret number can be chosen. After asking the playerâ€™s name, ask what she wants the highest possible number to be. Then, instead of choosing a random number between 1 and 10, choose a random number between 1 and the number the player requested.
  • Add code to keep track of how many guesses the player has made. After the player guesses correctly, inform her how many tries it took before the correct number was guessed.
  • Increase the playerâ€™s chances by telling her whether the guessed number is too high or too low instead of just that it is incorrect.

entry.title: ğŸ“ Pong!
entry.content:
â˜… Specifications â˜…

Gameplay

The ball bounces off the upper and lower edges of the field and the playersâ€™ paddles. Each time the ball bounces off a paddle, its speed increases by a small amount. When the ball bounces off a paddle, its direction is reversed with a small random variation to add unpredictability to the game. Itâ€™s like ping pong, but for nerds. Itâ€™s like ping pong.

Scoring

â­ If the ball touches the left or right edge of the field, a point is scored for the opposite player.
â­ When one player reaches 5 points, the game is over and that player is the winner. The winner is announced on the screen and the player is given the opportunity to start a new game.

Player Control

â­ Paddles are positioned a short distance away from the side they are defending, and can only move up and down, not side to side.
â­ The player can control the paddle with your choice of keys or the mouse.
â­ The other paddle should be controlled by THE COMPUTER

â˜‘ï¸ Checklist

Custom Blocks

  • Throughout your program, you should use custom blocks to generalize common operation, like keeping score.
  • Your program must include at least three custom blocks, at least one of which must take inputs.

Required Checkpoints

  • Players control their paddle.
  • The ball starts in the middle (INITIALIZE), moves in a random direction, and bounce.
  • The ball speeds up when it hits a paddle, and resets to the middle when it hits the left or right edge
  • A point is scored when the ball hits the edge on the opponentâ€™s side of the field; the game ends when one player reaches five points; players can start a new game after the game ends

entry.title: ğŸ‚ Lab 2âƒ£.3âƒ£ Defining Gravity
entry.content:
In this lab, you will use everything youâ€™ve learned about loops and conditionals to construct a simplified model for gravity.

What goes upâ€¦ğŸ¶

  1. Create a SNAP program with a background that looks like an outside scene. Add a single sprite that looks like an object of your choice (a brick or a ball would work well) and place it so it is touching the â€œground.â€
  2. Write code for your sprite so that, when the green flag is clicked, the object moves to the top of the stage and â€œfallsâ€ towards the bottom at a constant speed.
  3. What happens in your program when the object hits the â€œgroundâ€? Is that an accurate model of how gravity works on Earth?
  4. Modify your program so that the problem you identified in part 3 is fixed. Make your object do something appropriate when it hits the â€œground.â€ (Making sure the ground is a unique color and making use of that color will be helpful.

âœ… Check: Press Green Flag, object falls from top of the screen, hits the ground, and looks like itâ€™s hitting the ground.

â€¦Must Come Down

  1. Add a second sprite that looks like something that might already be on the ground when your first object is falling (like a house, a picnic table, a person, etc.). Put this new object directly below where the first object falls so that the falling object will hit it.
  2. What should happen when the following object hits the object on the ground? Will that happen with the model we currently have? Why or why not?
  3. Modify your code so that you fix the problem you identified in part 2.2. Make your falling object do something appropriate if it hits the object on the ground. Once youâ€™ve made that work, move the falling object and make sure you didnâ€™t break the situation when the falling object doesnâ€™t hit something on the way down.

âœ… Check: Code for a collision between two objects, and a miss.

  1. Add code so that both objects move to a random x coordinate every time the green flag is clicked. The falling object should be at the top of the stage, and the other object at the bottom. Verify that the falling object does the right thing no matter where the two objects end up relative to each other.

  2. Add a hill to your outdoor scene and make sure that your falling object does something appropriate when it hits the hill.

âœ… Check: Green Flag sets random position. Object falls, collides or â€œrolls.â€

entry.title: â¿ Nested Loops
entry.content:
ğŸ¯ Learning Target

I can use nested loops to solve programming problems.

Do Now (in Google Classroom)

Why are loops useful?

Letâ€™s look an example. Write code to draw two squares, next to each other.

â¬›â¬›

Nested Loops

A loop in a loop.

In other wordsâ€¦

How many times will the sprite take 20 steps?

Lab 2.2 - Itâ€™s Brick

In this lab, you will use nested loops to draw a large brick wall using as little code as possible.

Part 1 - Build a Brick

  1. Write a SNAP script to draw a single 20x10 â€œbrickâ€ in the lower left corner of the stage when the green flag is clicked.
  2. Modify your code to draw two bricks side by side. The bricks should share a short edge.
  3. Now modify your code again to build a full row of bricks across the entire length of the stage. Use loop to keep your code as concise as possible. Remember that the stage is 480 pixels wide and 360 pixels tall (by default- you can change that).

Part 2 - Build a Wall

  1. Now that you can build a row of bricks, add code to build a second row above the first row. The bricks in the second row should share a long edge with those in the first row, but should be â€œoffsetâ€ so that the ends of the second row bricks are at the middle of the first row bricks.
  2. Modify your code to build more rows, alternating back and forth between the â€œregularâ€ and â€œoffsetâ€ rows. Use nested loops to keep your code concise.
  3. Finish off the wall the by building alternating rows all the way to the top of the stage. Remember that the stage is 360 pixels tall. Your final wall should look like this:

Can you build the whole wall with one nested loop?

entry.title: ğŸ” Unit 2: Loops
entry.content:
ğŸ¯ Learning Target

I can explain that iteration is the repetition of part of an algorithm until a condition is met or for a specified number of times.

I can create loops in SNAP to reduce the complexity of an existing algorithm.

Do Now

What is a â€œloopâ€? Where have you seen them before?

Redundancy Data that can be left out without loss of function. Repitition. Readability Able to be read. Understandable.

Example

Loop

A type of block that causes other code to run multiple times in succession

Help with:

â†‘Readability of code

â†“Redundancy

Lab 2.1 - Geometric Fun Times v2.0â„¢

Remember when you drew all those shapes? Didnâ€™t it seem like it should be easier? Wellâ€¦

In this lab, you will rewrite your SNAP programs from Lab 1.3 to draw shapes using loops.

Section 1 - Back In Time

Open your solution to the original Lab 1.1. Go to the â€œFileâ€ menu and select â€œSave asâ€¦â€ to give your project a new name.

If your shapes are not already different colors and line-thicknesses, update them now.

Section 2 - Simplifying Code

  1. Look at your code to draw a square. It is probably quite long and has lots of repeated blocks. Using what you have learned about loops, rewrite this script to be shorter and have less redundancy. Make sure that your code still works as originally intended.
  2. Now modify your other shape scripts to also use loops. In all cases, try to have as few blocks and as little redundancy as possible while still keeping your code easy to read and understand.
  3. Do you notice a pattern for the number of sides of a shape, the number of repeat and the turn ğŸ”„ ___ degrees for each shape? Hmmâ€¦thatâ€™s interesting.

Section 3 - Letâ€™s be lazy.

Weâ€™re going to make a block called shape and make it do all the work for us. Add code to your program to draw the extra shapes below. Follow all the original guidelines (different color and line thickness for each shape, say the name while drawing) and use loops to keep your scripts as short as possible.

How can you draw a circle? Are you really drawing a circle?

entry.title: ğŸ”š Unit 1 Final Project
entry.content:
You will create a short animation in SNAP depicting a scene.

This could be a scene from a book/movie/play, depict lyrics from your favorite song, or your own unique animations

  • Whenever the green flag is clicked, your SNAP animation should display your chosen scene line by line somewhere on the stage. (This should work correctly even if the last run was interrupted and restart.)

  • As each line is shown, sprites should act out the story.

  • The animation should advance on its own, but should do so at a pace that allows each action to complete and the viewer to read the line before the next line is shown and new action begins.

  • In addition, the sprites must act out the scene; you should not simply create a series of static backgrounds or costumes that show a stop-motion version of the story.

  • Each line must be readable and must stay shown while the corresponding action is occurring.

  • When the story ends, there should be a way for the user to replay the entire animation from the beginning.

  • You are free to be as creative as you like with your choice of sprites and actions.

  • You may choose from the sprites provided by SNAP or create your own. (You will not be graded on your artistic skills.) You may interpret the scene literally or be clever with your depiction. However, all sprites, behaviors, words, and animations must be school-appropriate.

Implementation Details

As mentioned above, your animation must display the scene in its entirety and animate each line. Action must be performed by sprites and must consist of more than simply changing costumes. You must include the following components in your animation:

  • At least two sprites that act in some way to contribute to the depiction of the story

  • At least one sprite that moves

  • At least one sprite that rotates

  • At least one sprite that changes costume

  • At least one sprite that is both hidden and shown at some point

Note that multiple of these requirements may be satisfied by the same sprite (e.g. the same sprite can both move and change costume), but you must have at least two separate sprites that act in the animation.

Specifications

Functional Correctness (Behavior) Points
Animation depicts a full scene (or approved smaller portion) 2 points
Scene is shown one line at a time 2 points
Each line is accompanied by sprites depicting the story, and all action is related to the current line 3 points
Clicking green flag starts animation from beginning 1 point
Animation progresses at a reasonable pace 2 points
User is able to restart animation when it concludes 2 points
Total 12 points
**Technical Correctness (Implementation) ** Â 
Program shows good creativity and effort 2 points
At least two sprites participate in the action 2 points
At least one sprite moves 1 points
At least one sprite rotates 1 points
At least one sprite changes costume 1 points
At least one sprite hides and/or appears 1 points
Total 8 points
PROJECT TOTAL 20 points

entry.title: ğŸ¶ğŸ²ğŸƒ First Animation
entry.content:
In this lab, you will use costumes and movement to create simple SNAP animations.

ğŸ¶ Walk the Dog

1.1) In a SNAP project, click on the file menu, then click costumes. Import the costumes â€œdog2-bâ€ and â€œdog2-câ€.

1.2) Write a script to make the sprite change costume each time the spacebar is pressed. The sprite should switch back and forth between the two costumes.

1.3) Add code so that the sprite will face to the left, move a few steps, and change costume when the left arrow key is pressed. If youâ€™ve done it right, it should look like the dog is walking when you press the left arrow key repeatedly.

1.4) Add code so that the dog can walk to the right as well.

ğŸ² Dragons!

2.1) Create a new sprite. Following the same steps as in part 1.1, import the costumes â€œdragon1-aâ€ and â€œdragon1-bâ€

2.2) Write a script to make the sprite appear to breathe fire when the f key is pressed. The sprite should switch to the â€œfire-breathingâ€ costume for a few seconds, then switch back to the â€œnormalâ€ costume.

2.3) Modify your code so that the dragon â€œattacksâ€ the mouse pointer when the â€˜fâ€™ key is pressed. When the f key is pressed, the dragon should take the following actions in order:

  • Make sure it is in the â€œnormalâ€ costume
  • Point at the mouse pointer
  • Glide to the mouse pointerâ€™s position
  • Change to the â€œfire-breathingâ€ costume
  • Pause to breathe fire
  • Change back to the â€œnormalâ€ costume

ğŸƒ Run Away!

3.1) Add another sprite to your program. (This sprite can have any costume you choose.)

3.2) Write a script to make this new sprite point away from the dragon and move when the r key is pressed. (Youâ€™ll need more than one block to do this.)

3.3) Modify your code so that instead of moving when the r key is pressed, the new sprite moves when the dragon â€œattacks.â€ The â€œfleeingâ€ sprite should move when the dragon starts breathing fire.

3.4) Add a second sprite that runs away from the dragon as well.

entry.title: Lab 1âƒ£.1âƒ£
entry.content:
Geometric Fun Timesâ„¢

In this lab, you will write your first SNAP programs to draw some simple shapes on the stage.

1. Drawing a square

1.1) Write a SNAP script that draws a square when the number 1 is pressed on the keyboard. Remember that each corner of a square is a 90Â° angle.

1.2) Add code so that the sprite says the word â€œsquareâ€ while it is drawing. The sprite should stop saying â€œsquareâ€ once it has finished drawing the square.

1.3) Add code so that pressing the spacebar clears the pen marks from the stage.

Comment your code explaining your work.

2. Adding more shapes

2.1) Now that youâ€™ve drawn a square, add code to draw the shapes in the following table. Each shape should be drawn when the number next to it is pressed on the keyboard. (For example, pressing 3 on the keyboard should draw a diamond.)

When this key is pressed... Draw a ...
1 Square
2 Equilateral triangle
3 Diamond
4 Pentagon
5 Parallelogram ("leaning rectangle")
6 5-pointed star

You will probably want to draw a sketch of each to figure out the angles in each shape.

2.2) Add code so that as each shape is being drawn, the sprite is saying the name of shape. The sprite should stop saying the name of the sprite when it is finished drawing.

2.3) Modify your code so that each different shape is drawn in a different color and with a different line thickness. So, for example, if the square is drawn in blue with a line thickness of 3, each other shape must be drawn in a color that is not blue and with a line thickness that is not 3. You can choose whatever colors your want.

2.4) Add code so that the sprite is hidden when it is not drawing. This is will make sure that the sprite is not obstructing the view of your beautiful artwork!

3) Comment your code! What did you do? Where did you get stuck? How did you fix it?

entry.title: Lab 1âƒ£
entry.content:
ğŸ¯ Learning Targets

I can explain in writing the expected outcome of a piece of code.
I can complete a CS lab to specification.

ğŸ‘‰ Do Now

  1. Login to Classroom and open Lab 1.0.
  2. Complete the Do Now portion of the lab.

Lab Days

This is our first Lab Day. You will be working at your own pace on a series of programming challenges and projects. You are welcome to consult teachers or classmates for help or hints (and you are more than welcome to help others), but your work must be your own, and you must be able to explain it.

The expectation for Lab Days is that you are documenting your work in your code, giving credit to classmates or any other sources of assistance and inspiration.

Good luck, and have fun!

entry.title: ğŸ‰Hello World
entry.content:
ğŸ¯ Learning Target: I can describe the role of creativity in Computer Science.

ğŸ‘‰ Do Now: Why does the new iPhone 7 not have a headphone jack?
